title.narrative: Bridging the Gaps 2 - PWUD project South Africa

description.narrative: Bridging the Gaps works with a Theory of Change approach. A Theory of Change is a description of a list of events that is expected to lead to a particular desired outcome. It is a visualization how change is believed to happen. In 2016, representatives of the PWUD community developed a Theory of Change that consists of short-,medium, and long term outcomes. The specified Theory of Change of the PWUD project in South Africa describes how we plan to realize sustainable funding and improved access to inclusive community-based services (including harm reduction and OST); consideration of PWUD as legitimate community members and a strong national PWUD network. Through innovation and by building on previous work, we will strengthen civil society organisations’ ability to: 1. We facilitate community development - Training students and healthcare professionals on harm reduction, rights and policies. Building national PWUD network to improve human rights and health of PWUD. 2. We advocate for the continuously strengthening of services and upholding human rights - Documenting human rights violations and evidence-informed advocacy. Assessing the needs and risks of street-based PWUD to inform advocacy and programming. 3. We deliver inclusive, rights-based and gender sensitive services - Providing accessible health services for PWUD, for example through outreach and the supply of sterile needles and syringes and other harm reduction commodities. - Providing psychosocial services to PWUD through established drop in centres and safe spaces. - Designing and distributing harm reduction IEC materials for PWUD, including stimulant use, smoking, snorting and injecting drugs. - Coordinating a structural clean-up. - Facilitating capacity building of outreach workers and knowledge exchange. 4. We foster global and in-country process and partnerships that reinforce results - Strengthening relationships, networks and processes with government departments and the civil society drug policy network. - Establishing and participating in a ‘Friends of PWUD’ structure that helps capacitate and support PWUD networks until they are self-sustaining. - Establishing relationships with civil society and encouraging the development of harm reduction services and advocacy for effective rights based drug policies.
People who Use Drugs

The main drugs of choice in South Africa are alcohol, cannabis, heroin and methamphetamine. Methamphetamine is locally known as tik. Most heroin is smoked mixed with cannabis, a popular mix called whoonga, cocktail or nyope. Heroin injection, however, has been increasing in recent years. Harm reduction programmes were introduced in South Africa only in 2014, focusing on PWID. South Africa counts with a progressive legal framework around drug policies, supporting a harm reduction approach. Nevertheless, and despite being considered a middle-income country, government funding for harm reduction is still very limited. Moral issues around drugs play an important role in this disparity. With the help of Bridging the Gaps Program, in 2 years’ time 3 Needles and Syringe Programmes (NSP) for People who Inject Drugs (PWID) were built and developed in 3 key-cities (Cape Town, Durban and Pretoria). Some of the activities offered by the programmes are HIV prevention and testing, needle and syringe distribution, drop in centres, and referral to other services. On the advocacy side, Mainline supports the development of two recently born regional drug users’ networks, documentation of human rights violation towards PWUD, media articles on human rights for PWUD and national events to debate drug policies. One excellent example of such an event is the RUN 2016 – SA Drug Policy Week – link: http://www.sadrugpolicyweek.com/. As a result of advocacy efforts, 3 new Opiate Substitution Treatment (OST) pilots will start in 2017 in Durban (Kwazulu Natal), Cape Town (Western Cape) and Pretoria (Gauteng). To support this, Mainline recently delivered a training on OST to South African outreach workers, together with our local partners. Training focused on understanding the medical aspects of OST and possibilities of psychosocial assistance for OST clients. Read more about the training here: http://english.mainline.nl/posts/show/10139/training-on-opiate-substitution-treatment-in-south-africa

sector.narrative: Service delivery to PWID to prevent HIV infections

description.narrative: Commitment BtG2 ZA
Committment OUT ZA
commitment BtG2 ZA

2 Trained Service Providers Trained service providers is measured through 2 indicators. The first measures the number of service providers trained. Service providers provide social services, including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, or health NGO or public sector services. The counselling part of VCT services is excluded. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners for instance other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc. The second measures the number of legal service providers trained including paralegal services

2A # of service providers trained. This is the number of individual service providers meaning staff members, trained by alliance partner and/or by a country partner. Total # is the number of people trained by alliance partner and number of people trained by partners. Service providers provide social (including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, NOT the counselling part of VCT services), or health(NGO or public sector) services. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners (e.g. other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc).

comment.narrative: The trained individuals consisted of: Project Staff, Staff from Organisational Partners, Outreach workers, 4th year Medical Students and Service Beneficiaries.
There were Medical students, Theology students, representatives of local city government, staff of affiliated CSO's and project staff trained on Harm reduction

description.narrative: 2B # legal service providers trained including paralegal services

title.narrative: 3 Law enforcement staff trained on human rights

description.narrative: 3 Law enforcement staff trained on human rights Law enforcement staff trained on human rights is measured by the number of law enforcement staff trained on human rights.

title.narrative: 3 # law enforcement staff trained on human rights

description.narrative: 3 # law enforcement staff trained on human rights

comment.narrative: 101 Law Enforcement officers and members were trained in the "Dignity and Diversity training"
150 Law Enforcement officers were trained in the "Dignity and Diversity training"

title.narrative: 5 Human Rights violation cases acted on

description.narrative: 5 Human Rights violation cases acted on Human rights violation cases acted on is the number of violations documented and in the process of being acted on, instead of responded to, meaning that the cases are taken further than documentation, for example reporting, providing psychosocial and or paralegal or legal support.

title.narrative: 5 # human rights violation cases acted on

description.narrative: 5 # human rights violation cases acted on. This is the number of violations documented and in the process of being acted on, instead of ‘responded to’, meaning that the cases are taken further than documentation, for example reporting, providing psychosocial and or paralegal or legal support.

comment.narrative: Although only 3 cases are responded to by providing legal and or paralegal support, 10 other cases are documented and the local PWUD network is looking into ways of taken it further.

In 2019, South Africa has seen local outbursts of violence against foreigners, Uber drivers and (alleged) drug dealers, which disproportionately also affected people who use drugs. Therefore, there is a higher number of human right violation cases compared to pervious years. However, the number of cases acted on (54), is a fraction of the overal cases reported.

title.narrative: 4 Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings

description.narrative: Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations that participate in meetings. Meetings are defined as advocacy meetings with local national regional or global stakeholders.

title.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings

description.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations. Meetings are advocacy meetings with local/national/regional/global stakeholders.

comment.narrative: - 7 meetings with local government -5 meetings with harm reduction stakeholders (crisis meeting) and funders - 2 meetings with learning institutes/ local universities - 2 conferences

title.narrative: 1 Service provision to Key Population Members

description.narrative: Service provision to key population members measures the number of services used by key population members. This is done through 6 indicators that respectively measure the number of testing services, treatment services, PWUD specific medical harm reduction services, other health services meaning condom distribution, social services and legal support services used by key population members.

title.narrative: 1C # of KP members using PWUD specific medical harm reduction services

description.narrative: 1C # of KP members using PWUD specific medical harm reduction services (disaggregated by age) including needle exchange, OST, OD prevention, PWUD specific counselling

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years. Mainline and partners have additional dimensions which are used to monitor reach of services: Male, female and other. Although no target has been set, our partners in South Africa have surpassed the number of individuals reached compared to the previous years. The data shown are the aggregated results of two partners and is next to BtG, co-funded by PEPFAR and Global Fund
